content:
Hello --

In going through a video about queries,
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5AqVVfd-dI4&t=232s

I made a mistake and, instead of entering a query for subject 500

GET http://fhir.hl7fundamentals.org/r4/Observation?subject=500

I typed

http://fhir.hl7fundamentals.org/r4/Observation?_subject=500

and still got an answer back for the typo, with different content.

Why? Is this a bug or a feature? What could the meaning of "_subject" possibly be?

This was from
X-Powered-By: HAPI FHIR 3.7.0-SNAPSHOT REST Server (FHIR Server; FHIR 4.0.0/R4)
Server: Jetty(9.4.12.v20180830)

TIA
-- Henry
If a search parameter isn't recognized, it'll generally be ignored. The search parameters actually used will be reflected in the 'self' link in the search response

Thanks, Lloyd, but the server didn't seem to ignore the underscore syntax.
And I saw no mention of "_subject" parameter in "self" in any of these?
http://fhir.hl7fundamentals.org/r4/Observation?subject=500
http://fhir.hl7fundamentals.org/r4/Observation?_subject=500
Perhaps I didn't quite get what you meant, since I'm new at this.
Could it possibly be a bug, the server accepting "_subject" and returning patient data?
If you search simply http://fhir.hl7fundamentals.org/r4/Observation what do you get back? Is it the same result you get from http://fhir.hl7fundamentals.org/r4/Observation?_subject=500 ?
It is ignoring the _subject. The first query is only returning observations with a subject of Patient/500. The second query is returning all observations.
Yes, Jean that's correct. Sorry, that was a bit confusing. It was ignored, like Lloyd said. Thanks to Michele too, for pointing that out by way of experiment.
Hank Lenzi has marked this topic as resolved.
